title: Opinion: Nationals back Daniel Hudson's decision to go on paternity leave, showing baseball isn't life
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: USA TODAY Sports' Steve Gardner previews the NLCS showdown between the Washington Nationals and St. Louis Cardinals. USA TODAY

ST. LOUIS – Daniel Hudson won’t pitch Friday night in Game 1 of the National League Championship Series – a game that may or may not have required his services – and it’s kind of a big deal that it’s not a big deal.

Hudson has been the Washington Nationals’ most important relief pitcher in this postseason, locking down saves in the NL wild-card game and in Game 2 of the NL Division Series. Less than 48 hours ago, he pitched one of the most important single innings in Nationals postseason history – setting down the Dodgers on just one hit in Game 5’s bottom of the ninth, keeping the game tied and enabling Howie Kendrick’s historic grand slam to vault Washington into its first NLCS an inning later.

In the booze-fueled aftermath at Dodger Stadium, Hudson told reporters he’d be heading to his Arizona home on the off day between series to be with his wife, Sara, who was due to give birth to their third child.

As children are prone to do, No. 3 didn’t cooperate.

“Apparently,” Nationals manager Dave Martinez said Friday, “the baby didn’t want to come out until later on this morning.”

Nationals closer has to postseason saves. (Photo: Brad Mills, USA TODAY Sports)

And so Hudson was placed on the paternity list, and the Nationals will go forth without him in the biggest game in franchise history (a designation that will apply for every game the remainder of this month).

And somehow, the St. Louis Arch is still standing.

Martinez fielded exactly one question on the matter before Game 1 and admittedly, it might have been different if Hudson were Juan Soto or Anthony Rendon or Max Scherzer on a day he was starting.

After all, Hudson may not figure in this game. The Nationals could win 13-1 or they could lose 9-0 and Hudson wouldn’t so much as taken off his jacket in the visiting bullpen.

Still, the relative non-furor shows the world has come a long way from even 2014, when New York Mets infielder Daniel Murphy was pilloried by area talk show hosts – including former NFL quarterback Boomer Esiason – for missing the Mets’ first two games of the season as his wife gave birth.

Esiason even went so far as to suggest Murphy should have strong-armed his wife into a C-section.

Yeah.

“We’re going to miss him today,” Martinez said, “and he’s going to try to get back here possibly tomorrow. But I told him, ‘Hey, family’s always first.’ I mean, I get it, I understand.

“The timing didn’t work out like we thought, the baby wasn’t ready to come out. So we get him back when we get him back.”

Given that most major leaguers fall within the ages of 22 and 35, managers often find themselves tracking contractions as often as transactions, and Martinez is no different. The Nationals had quite a summertime baby boom, with Scherzer, Hunter Strickland and Brian Dozier all leaving the club to be with their families.

Now’s probably a good time to note that Hudson began the season a Toronto Blue Jay, and he and Sara could be forgiven if, nine months prior, they felt their calendar would be relatively clear come mid-October. But a July 31 trade to Washington thrust them into a pennant race and after getting through three elimination games, here they are, juggling an NLCS and a newborn.

It’s a handy reminder that baseball isn’t life, just a wonderful part of it -- unpredictable and unscripted and largely uncontrollable.

For Hudson, the two intersected at a wild yet wonderful time. “It’s clearly a blessing having a baby,” Cardinals manager Mike Shildt said.

So, too, is competing for a World Series championship. That can wait.

Life can’t.
description: Nationals closer Daniel Hudson goes on paternity leave to start the NLCS against the St. Louis Cardinals -- a handy reminder that baseball isn’t life.
